pullrequest.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

content.raw:
I'm not sure what's the usual procedure in these cases, but here, if you play an old log file you get two errors:

~~~
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:134] Log file header is missing the log start time.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:144] Log file header is missing the log end time.
~~~

To me, it feels like it should be some warning somehow about the log version instead of an error. In fact, maybe we should change the log version from 1.0 to 2.0 since by the time gazebo 6 comes out, the files will have very different structures?
content.html:
I'm not sure what's the usual procedure in these cases, but here, if you play an old log file you get two errors:

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:134] Log file header is missing the log start time.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:144] Log file header is missing the log end time.

To me, it feels like it should be some warning somehow about the log version instead of an error. In fact, maybe we should change the log version from 1.0 to 2.0 since by the time gazebo 6 comes out, the files will have very different structures?

pullrequest.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

content.raw:
How about a function that returns the whole path? Currently Gazebo always saves the logs at `~/.gazebo/log/<date and time>/gzserver/state.log`, so this function is always returning just `state.log`. 

I'm not sure if it would be more useful to have a separate function for the path and keep this one for the name or just have one for the full path, what do you think?
content.html:
How about a function that returns the whole path? Currently Gazebo always saves the logs at ~/.gazebo/log/<date and time>/gzserver/state.log, so this function is always returning just state.log.

I'm not sure if it would be more useful to have a separate function for the path and keep this one for the name or just have one for the full path, what do you think?
